facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 928 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 928 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 14, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 57 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 14, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 57 of 959.

facts.text: Phool Chand is the predecessor-in-title of the appellant Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand.

anchor.surface_text: One Phool Chand, the predecessor-in-title of the appellant Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand, instituted a suit against the respondent, the Union of India

facts.text: Phool Chand instituted a suit against the Union of India in the Court of the Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: instituted a suit against the respondent, the Union of India, in the Court of the Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, and obtained a decree

facts.text: Phool Chand obtained a decree on 25-4-1951 for Rs. 24,234-14-0 and proportionate costs with interest at 4 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: and obtained a decree on 25-4-1951 for Rs. 24,234-14-0 and proportionate costs with interest 4 per annum.

facts.text: The respondent challenged the decree by preferring an appeal in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the said decree by preferring an appeal in the High Court.

facts.text: Pending the appeal, the respondent deposited the decretal amount of Rs. 31,849-9-9.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal, the respondent deposited the decretal amount of Rs. 31.849-9-9.

facts.text: On December 14, 1952, Phool Chand withdrew Rs. 28,032-12-0 out of the deposited amount after furnishing security.

anchor.surface_text: On December 14, 1952, phool Chand withdrew Rs. 28.032-12-0 out of the said amount after furnishing due security in that behalf.

facts.text: The respondent's appeal was partly allowed on June 26, 1954, and the decretal amount was reduced to Rs. 10,971-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the respondents appeal was partly allowed on June 26, 1954, and the decretal amount was reduced to Rs. 10,971-15-6.

facts.text: Phool Chand had withdrawn Rs. 15,340-14-8 in excess of his legitimate dues.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the total decretal amount due to the decree- holder Phool Chand came to Rs. 12,691-13-6 and that meant that he had withdrawn Rs. 15,340-14-8

facts.text: On September 4, 1954, the respondent applied for restitution of the excess amount and claimed interest thereon.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4. 1954, the respondent applied for restitution of the said amount and claimed interest thereon.

facts.text: The Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, allowed the respondent's application for restitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, allowed the said application, and in execution of it,

facts.text: In execution, the respondent sought recovery by attachment and sale of certain immovable properties of Phool Chand.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent sought for the recovery of the said amount by attachment and sale of certain immovable properties of Phool Chand, mentioned in the application.

facts.text: The properties were sold by Phool Chand to the appellant by a registered sale deed executed on January 9, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: But, meanwhile, they had been sold by Phool Chand to the appellant by a registered sale deed executed on January 9, 1953.

facts.text: The appellant objected to the attachment under O.21 r.58.

anchor.surface_text: That is why the appellant objected to the said attachment under O.21 r. 58 of the Code.

facts.text: The appellant's objection was over-ruled and dismissed by the Second Additional District Judge on April 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: but his objection was over-ruled and his application was dismissed by the Second Additional District Judge on April 16, 1957.

facts.text: The appellant gave notice to the respondent under s.80 on April 12, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Before the appellant filed the present suit on June 23,1958 in the Court of the First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, he gave notice to the respondent under s. 80

facts.text: The appellant filed the suit under O.21 r.63 on June 23, 1958 in the Court of the First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: Before the appellant filed the present suit on June 23,1958 in the Court of the First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur,

facts.text: In the suit, the appellant claimed declaration that the properties could not be attached and sold as title vested in him by valid sale deed, and injunction.

anchor.surface_text: In the said suit, he claimed a declaration that the properties in question could not be attached and sold inasmuch as the title in respect of the said properties vested in him by virtue of a valid sale deed executed in his favour by Phool Chand. The appellant also claimed an injunction

facts.text: The respondent raised a plea of limitation in defence.

anchor.surface_text: In defence, the respondent raised a plea of limitation.

facts.text: It is common ground that limitation for suit under O.21 r.63 is one year from the date of the order under O.21 r.58 by Article 11 of Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the period of limitation prescribed for a suit under O. 21 r. 63 by Article 11 of the Limitation Act is one year from the date of the order under O. 21. r.

facts.text: If s.80 applies and notice period excluded, the suit is within time.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if s. 80 applies to the present suit and the period covered by the notice served by the appellant on the respondent can be taken into account, the suit is within time.

facts.text: If s.80 does not apply and notice period not excluded, the suit is barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: It is also not disputed that if s. 80 does not apply to the present suit and the period of the notice cannot be taken into account, the suit is barred by time

facts.text: The trial Judge and the High Court of Madhya Pradesh held s.80 does not apply, dismissed suit as barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned trial Judge and the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, Jabalpur, have answered this question against the appellant, and the suit has, therefore, been dismissed as barred by time.

facts.text: The appellant appealed to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellant has come to this Court with a certificate granted by the said High Court.

holdings.text: A suit instituted under O. 21 r. 63 of the Code of Civil Procedure is a suit against the Government and attracts the provisions of s. 80 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether a suit filed in pursuance of O. 21 r. 63 of the Code of Civil Procedure attracts the, provisions of s.80 of the Code. This point arises in this way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.80 uses wide, unambiguous, express, explicit and mandatory words applying to all suits against Government; r.63 proceedings are a regular suit commenced by plaint under s.26, treated as suit for limitation under Art.11, challenging r.58 order on title and possession.

holdings.text: s.80 admits of no implications or exceptions; cannot add words of exception to exclude suits under O.21 r.63.

anchor.surface_text: it would be difficult to except from their operation any proceeding which can be regarded as a suit against the Government. While dealing with the applicability of s. 80, the question to ask is is it a suit against the Government or number?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language governs; acceding to exception would require adding words to statute, not permissible.

holdings.text: Suit under O.21 r.63 is not a mere continuation of attachment proceedings under r.58 or a form of appeal such that it falls outside s.80.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, said that the suit under O. 21 r. 63 is a continuation of attachment proceedings and as such, cannot be regarded as a suit proper which is included within the purview of s. 80.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phul Kumari limited to court fees under specific article for old s.283; unreasonable to extend observations to all purposes like s.80 applicability.

holdings.text: Scope of enquiry under O.21 r.63 suit is wider (title and possession) than summary r.58 investigation (possession only), with r.58 order as cause of action.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we ought to bear in mind that the scope of the enquiry under O. 21 r. 58 is very limited, and is confined to questions of possession as therein indicated while suit brought under O. 21 r. 63.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of rules distinguishes proceedings; confirms independent suit nature subject to s.80.

holdings.text: Notice under s.80 is mandatory regardless of Government's prior knowledge from r.58 proceedings or purpose of affording settlement opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that no notice can be said to be required for suits under O. 21 r. 63, because the principal object for enacting s. 80 is absent in the case of such suits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain words prevail over purpose; Amar Nath confirms notice necessity even if prior notice suffices for subsequent suits; Bhagchand mandates literal interpretation without exceptions based on procedure or object.

holdings.text: Following Bhagchand Dagadusa, s.80 applies to all suits against Government including those for injunction or under O.21 r.63, without procedural exceptions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council held s.80 express and mandatory per natural meaning, rejecting purposive or injustice-based exceptions; applies equally here.

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 80 applies to all suits including for injunction whatever relief sought as it is express explicit and mandatory admitting no implications or exceptions
precedents.cited_holding: s. 80 applied to suits where injunction was claimed
